instances.text: APBI_V 361-199 - Key Indicators of Agroecosystem Sustainability

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: If you meet the requirements for the course/waitlist but are not able to self-register, please fill out this 2024 Winter Session Registration Request for LFS Courses form. An LFS Academic Advisor will assess your eligibility for registration and you will be notified accordingly.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Please use the UBC Directory to find your instructor/TA contact information.

instances.text: ARBC_V 302-001 - Intermediate Classical and Quranic Arabic II

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Intermediate Classical and Quranic Arabic II. Visit amne.ubc.ca for full course descriptions.

If the course is full or blocked, or if you do not meet restrictions for the available seats, please register for the waitlist. Students will be moved manually from the waitlist into the course section in order of registration. If the course is blocked but showing available seats, this is normal and means that waitlist transfer have not yet taken place. Email amne.undergrad@ubc.cawith any questions.

instances.text: ARCL_V 309-001 - The Archaeology of Collapse and Sustainability
ARTH_V 300-002 - Seminar on Methods and Approaches in Art History

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: This seminar will appeal to art history majors and other upper-level students interested in historical and theoretical investigations of media and visual culture. Through discussion and the close reading of artworks and texts, students will become familiar with a range of influential and contentious approaches to defining Art andevaluating cultural artifacts. We will practice humility and learn to recognize power dynamics and patterns of objectification as we consider what is involved in acts of interpretation, classification, periodization, and speaking for objects and others.

instances.text: ARTH_V 309-001 - Arts of Africa and the African Diasporas

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Engaging with hands-on research based on the African collections of the UBC Museum of Anthropology, this course takes a comparative and historical approach to the arts of Africa and the African diasporas, exploring distinct formulations of what constitutes art in different parts of Africa and diasporic contexts. The course explores key debates that have framed the histories of African Art  tradition vs. innovation vs. authenticity; ethnic arts vs. national arts; art practices under colonial rule; modern African nations and national arts; international circulation of African arts and artists; markets, ownership, repatriation and reparation  and investigates their contemporary resonances.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: The eighteenth century  often referred to as the Age of Enlightenment  saw a series of profound social, geopolitical, and philosophical changes throughout Europe and the world at large. This course examines the artistic responses to these political and cultural revolutions beginning with the death of King Louis XIV of France (1715) through the Romantic revolutions of the 1830s. While attending most closely to European art, global trade networks and the spread of colonialism will bring us into contact with artistic movements in the Americas, the Caribbean, and East Asia.

instances.text: ARTH_V 341-001 - 20th Century Art and Culture: The Postmodern

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: American and European Art since 1945: What is Post-Modernism? provides an overview of visual art across media and the built environment in Europe and its North American diaspora from 1945 to 2008, situated within their social, political, and historical contexts with a special emphasis on major movements of the neo avant-garde which include The New York School, The Aesthetics of Indifference, Pop, Minimalism, Happenings, Performance, text-based Conceptual Art Installation, Delegated Performance and the repeated return of the avant-gardes, specifically of Dada and the readymade. Special emphasis is placed on the theoretical and social turns of the post medium condition, and above all on the advent of identity politics as a central criteria of art after the dissolution of the importance of skill-based media.

instances.text: ARTH_V 358-001 - Chinese Art for the Afterlife

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Tombs are not only important repositories for art objects and archaeological artefacts, they are also architectural structures that integrate objects and images into a spatial logic and create multi-layered meanings: Tombs are spaces of transformation, ritual spaces, and liminal zones; they envision the afterlife and show the tomb occupants ambitions. We will conduct case studies of Chinese tombs with a focus on the period between the Han and Yuan dynasties (third century BCE to the fourteenth century) to explore ideas about the afterlife, materiality, intercultural exchange, and the articulation of social identities.

instances.text: ARTH_V 362-001 - Art in Japan: Objects and Spaces

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: ARTH 362 explores the changing relationship between spaces and things in the Japanese archipelago. Students will learn to account for the co-imbrication of (art) objects and architectural typologies within changing social contexts. Students will be evaluated based on a combination of cumulative revision (exams) and individual research output.

instances.text: ARTH_V 377-001 - Arts of the Northwest Coast Peoples: The South

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Arts of the Northwest Coast Peoples (The South): Re-Examining Underrecognized Visual Cultures of Southern British Columbia, Washington, & the Peripheries
This lecture-based course examines ancient and historical Indigenous art forms of the southern Northwest Coast, defined as southern British Columbia, Washington, Oregon, and northern California. This region is severely underrepresented in Native Northwest art history, where scholarship tends to emphasize the bold, colorful artwork emanating from northern First Nations including the Haida, Tlingit, and Tsimshian. Redirecting our attention to local settings, we explore the more understated, abstract material culture found in southern locales, with a particular focus on Coast Salish art. In addition, we investigate why different genres of Northwest Coast art exist, and how these diverse styles have been categorized, classified, and even mischaracterized by scholars throughout the decades. Through textual analysis, discussion, research, and public art on campus, we will investigate various mediums: petroglyphs and stone carvings in archaeological contexts; monumental art, architecture, and welcome posts; and belongings such as masks, regalia, and weavings. By the end of the course, you will be able to identify nuances in southern Northwest Coast artistic expression, hypothesize possible reasons for these differences, and possess a greater understanding of Native art traditions in proximity to Vancouver and UBC.

(Note: Thiscourse is now offered as part of UBCs newly required Ways of Knowing curriculum, where ARTH 377 is listed as a Place & Power class. Place & Power courses offer students new ways to examine local landscapes through the lenses of settler colonialism, decolonialism, Indigeneity, environmental justice, etc.)

uiLabels.WDRES.FACETEDSEARCH.SymanSyntax:
Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
